page.title: 16COASTAL EROSION,WITHERNSEA
page.content: The Withernsea coast comprises of Glacial Drift material from the last ice age.It is of soft material,forming low cliffs,easily eroded by the sea at a rate of 2 metres per year.The sea removes material from the cliff base, causing the upper section to slump during periods of wet weather when the clay becomes saturated and lubricated with water.Longshore Drift and currents remove the material out to sea and southwards along the coast. At Withernsea a sloping concrete sea wall protects the built-up area from erosion.The base of the wall is protected from being undermined by the sea using a series of wooden groynes built out at right angles to the wall to low tide level. These prevent the beach from being totally removed by longshore drift and destructive waves.
